para.personname: CLAUDIO, a young lord of Florence.
BENEDICK, a young lord of Padua.

section.title: SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.
section.para: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon
comes this night to Messina.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off
when I left him.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: But few of any sort, and none of name.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings
home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath
bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by
Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the
promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a lamb,
the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better
bettered expectation than you must expect of me to
tell you how.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much
glad of it.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: I have already delivered him letters, and there
appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could
not show itself modest enough without a badge of
bitterness.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Did he break out into tears?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: In great measure.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces
truer than those that are so washed. How much
better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the
wars or no?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such
in the army of any sort.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: What is he that you ask for, niece?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever he was.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged
Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading
the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged
him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he
killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath
he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much;
but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it:
he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an
excellent stomach.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: And a good soldier too, lady.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all
honourable virtues.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man:
but for the stuffing,--well, we are all mortal.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a
kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her:
they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit
between them.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last
conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and
now is the whole man governed with one: so that if
he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him
bear it for a difference between himself and his
horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left,
to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his
companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Is't possible?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as
the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the
next block.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: No; an he were, I would burn my study. But, I pray
you, who is his companion? Is there no young
squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he
is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker
runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if
he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a
thousand pound ere a' be cured.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: I will hold friends with you, lady.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Do, good friend.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: You will never run mad, niece.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: No, not till a hot January.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Don Pedro is approached.

section.para: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your
trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid
cost, and you encounter it.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of
your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should
remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow abides
and happiness takes his leave.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this
is your daughter.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Her mother hath many times told me so.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this
what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers
herself. Be happy, lady; for you are like an
honourable father.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not
have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as
like him as she is.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior
Benedick: nobody marks you.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Is it possible disdain should die while she hath
such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?
Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come
in her presence.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I
am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and I
would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard
heart; for, truly, I love none.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: A dear happiness to women: they would else have
been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God
and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that: I
had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man
swear he loves me.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some
gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate
scratched face.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere such
a face as yours were.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and
so good a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's
name; I have done.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio
and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath
invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at
the least a month; and he heartily prays some
occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no
hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.
Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to
the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank
you.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Please it your grace lead on?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

section.para: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Is she not a modest young lady?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for
my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak
after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high
praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little
for a great praise: only this commendation I can
afford her, that were she other than she is, she
were unhandsome; and being no other but as she is, I
do not like her.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me
truly how thou likest her.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Can the world buy such a jewel?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this
with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting Jack,
to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a
rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man take
you, to go in the song?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I
looked on.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such
matter: there's her cousin, an she were not
possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty
as the first of May doth the last of December. But I
hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the
contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world
one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?
Shall I never see a bachelor of three-score again?
Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck
into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away
Sundays. Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: What secret hath held you here, that you followed
not to Leonato's?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb
man; I would have you think so; but, on my
allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He is
in love. With who? now that is your grace's part.
Mark how short his answer is;--With Hero, Leonato's
short daughter.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If this were so, so were it uttered.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is not so, nor
'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be
so.'

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it
should be otherwise.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: By my troth, I speak my thought.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: That I love her, I feel.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: That she is worthy, I know.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: That I neither feel how she should be loved nor
know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that
fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite
of beauty.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And never could maintain his part but in the force
of his will.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she
brought me up, I likewise give her most humble
thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my
forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick,
all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do
them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the
right to trust none; and the fine is, for the which
I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord,
not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood
with love than I will get again with drinking, pick
out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me
up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of
blind Cupid.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou
wilt prove a notable argument.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot
at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on
the shoulder, and called Adam.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Well, as time shall try: 'In time the savage bull
doth bear the yoke.'

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible
Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and set
them in my forehead: and let me be vilely painted,
and in such great letters as they write 'Here is
good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign
'Here you may see Benedick the married man.'

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in
Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I look for an earthquake too, then.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Well, you temporize with the hours. In the
meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to
Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will
not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made
great preparation.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I have almost matter enough in me for such an
embassage; and so I commit you--

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,--

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your
discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and
the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere
you flout old ends any further, examine your
conscience: and so I leave you.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: My liege, your highness now may do me good.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: No child but Hero; she's his only heir.
Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: O, my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye,
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant, in their rooms
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Thou wilt be like a lover presently
And tire the hearer with a book of words.
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,
And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: How sweetly you do minister to love,
That know love's grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity.
Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy.
I know we shall have revelling to-night:
I will assume thy part in some disguise
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after to her father will I break;
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.
In practise let us put it presently.

section.title: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: How now, brother! Where is my cousin, your son?
hath he provided this music?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell
you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Are they good?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: As the event stamps them: but they have a good
cover; they show well outward. The prince and Count
Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine
orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine:
the prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my
niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it
this night in a dance: and if he found her
accordant, he meant to take the present time by the
top and instantly break with you of it.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and
question him yourself.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear
itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal,
that she may be the better prepared for an answer,
if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell her of it.
Cousins, you know what you have to do. O, I cry you
mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will use your
skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy time.

linegroup.speaker: CONRADE
linegroup.line: What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out
of measure sad?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds;
therefore the sadness is without limit.

linegroup.speaker: CONRADE
linegroup.line: You should hear reason.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?

linegroup.speaker: CONRADE
linegroup.line: If not a present remedy, at least a patient
sufferance.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayest thou art,
born under Saturn, goest about to apply a moral
medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot hide
what I am: I must be sad when I have cause and smile
at no man's jests, eat when I have stomach and wait
for no man's leisure, sleep when I am drowsy and
tend on no man's business, laugh when I am merry and
claw no man in his humour.

linegroup.speaker: CONRADE
linegroup.line: Yea, but you must not make the full show of this
till you may do it without controlment. You have of
late stood out against your brother, and he hath
ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is
impossible you should take true root but by the
fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful
that you frame the season for your own harvest.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in
his grace, and it better fits my blood to be
disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob
love from any: in this, though I cannot be said to
be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied
but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with
a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I
have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my
mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty, I would do
my liking: in the meantime let me be that I am and
seek not to alter me.

linegroup.speaker: CONRADE
linegroup.line: Can you make no use of your discontent?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I make all use of it, for I use it only.
Who comes here?
What news, Borachio?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: I came yonder from a great supper: the prince your
brother is royally entertained by Leonato: and I
can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Will it serve for any model to build mischief on?
What is he for a fool that betroths himself to
unquietness?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Even he.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks
he?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a
musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio, hand
in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind the
arras; and there heard it agreed upon that the
prince should woo Hero for himself, and having
obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Come, come, let us thither: this may prove food to
my displeasure. That young start-up hath all the
glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way, I
bless myself every way. You are both sure, and will assist me?

linegroup.speaker: CONRADE
linegroup.line: To the death, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the
greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were of
my mind! Shall we go prove what's to be done?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: We'll wait upon your lordship.

section.title: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
section.para: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Was not Count John here at supper?

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: I saw him not.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see
him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: He were an excellent man that were made just in the
midway between him and Benedick: the one is too
like an image and says nothing, and the other too
like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's
mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior
Benedick's face,--

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money
enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman
in the world, if a' could get her good-will.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a
husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: In faith, she's too curst.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's
sending that way; for it is said, 'God sends a curst
cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Just, if he send me no husband; for the which
blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and
evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband with a
beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel
and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath a
beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no
beard is less than a man: and he that is more than
a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a
man, I am not for him: therefore, I will even take
sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and lead his
apes into hell.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Well, then, go you into hell?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: No, but to the gate; and there will the devil meet
me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and
say 'Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to
heaven; here's no place for you maids:' so deliver
I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the
heavens; he shows me where the bachelors sit, and
there live we as merry as the day is long.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: To HERO Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled
by your father.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy
and say 'Father, as it please you.' But yet for all
that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else
make another curtsy and say 'Father, as it please
me.'

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Not till God make men of some other metal than
earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be
overmastered with a pierce of valiant dust? to make
an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?
No, uncle, I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren;
and, truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince
do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be
not wooed in good time: if the prince be too
important, tell him there is measure in every thing
and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero:
wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch jig,
a measure, and a cinque pace: the first suit is hot
and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as
fantastical; the wedding, mannerly-modest, as a
measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes
repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into the
cinque pace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.

section.para: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing,
I am yours for the walk; and especially when I walk away.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: With me in your company?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: I may say so, when I please.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: And when please you to say so?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: When I like your favour; for God defend the lute
should be like the case!

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Speak low, if you speak love.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: Well, I would you did like me.

linegroup.speaker: MARGARET
linegroup.line: So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many
ill-qualities.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: Which is one?

linegroup.speaker: MARGARET
linegroup.line: I say my prayers aloud.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

linegroup.speaker: MARGARET
linegroup.line: God match me with a good dancer!

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: Amen.

linegroup.speaker: MARGARET
linegroup.line: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is
done! Answer, clerk.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: No more words: the clerk is answered.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: At a word, I am not.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: I know you by the waggling of your head.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: You could never do him so ill-well, unless you were
the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down: you
are he, you are he.

linegroup.speaker: ANTONIO
linegroup.line: At a word, I am not.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your
excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? Go to,
mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's an
end.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Will you not tell me who told you so?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: No, you shall pardon me.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Not now.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit
out of the 'Hundred Merry Tales:'--well this was
Signior Benedick that said so.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: What's he?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I am sure you know him well enough.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Not I, believe me.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Did he never make you laugh?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I pray you, what is he?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Why, he is the prince's jester: a very dull fool;
only his gift is in devising impossible slanders:
none but libertines delight in him; and the
commendation is not in his wit, but in his villany;
for he both pleases men and angers them, and then
they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in
the fleet: I would he had boarded me.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on me;
which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at,
strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a
partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no
supper that night.
We must follow the leaders.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: In every good thing.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at
the next turning.

section.para: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath
withdrawn her father to break with him about it.
The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Are not you Signior Benedick?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: You know me well; I am he.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Signior, you are very near my brother in his love:
he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade him
from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may
do the part of an honest man in it.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: How know you he loves her?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I heard him swear his affection.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her to-night.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Come, let us to the banquet.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love:
Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues;
Let every eye negotiate for itself
And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Count Claudio?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Yea, the same.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Come, will you go with me?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Whither?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Even to the next willow, about your own business,
county. What fashion will you wear the garland of?
about your neck, like an usurer's chain? or under
your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear
it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: I wish him joy of her.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so they
sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would
have served you thus?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: I pray you, leave me.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the
boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges.
But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not
know me! The prince's fool! Ha? It may be I go
under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I
am apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it
is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice
that puts the world into her person and so gives me
out. Well, I'll be revenged as I may.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Now, signior, where's the count? did you see him?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame.
I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a
warren: I told him, and I think I told him true,
that your grace had got the good will of this young
lady; and I offered him my company to a willow-tree,
either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or
to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: To be whipped! What's his fault?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being
overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his
companion, and he steals it.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The
transgression is in the stealer.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made,
and the garland too; for the garland he might have
worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on
you, who, as I take it, have stolen his birds' nest.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to
the owner.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith,
you say honestly.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the
gentleman that danced with her told her she is much
wronged by you.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block!
an oak but with one green leaf on it would have
answered her; my very visor began to assume life and
scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been
myself, that I was the prince's jester, that I was
duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest
with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood
like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at
me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs:
if her breath were as terrible as her terminations,
there were no living near her; she would infect to
the north star. I would not marry her, though she
were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before
he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have
turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make
the fire too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find
her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God
some scholar would conjure her; for certainly, while
she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a
sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose, because they
would go thither; so, indeed, all disquiet, horror
and perturbation follows her.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Look, here she comes.

section.para: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Will your grace command me any service to the
world's end? I will go on the slightest errand now
to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on;
I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the
furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of
Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the great
Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pigmies,
rather than hold three words' conference with this
harpy. You have no employment for me?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: None, but to desire your good company.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot
endure my Lady Tongue.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of
Signior Benedick.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave
him use for it, a double heart for his single one:
marry, once before he won it of me with false dice,
therefore your grace may well say I have lost it.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I
should prove the mother of fools. I have brought
Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Not sad, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: How then? sick?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Neither, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor
well; but civil count, civil as an orange, and
something of that jealous complexion.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true;
though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is
false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and
fair Hero is won: I have broke with her father,
and his good will obtained: name the day of
marriage, and God give thee joy!

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my
fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and an
grace say Amen to it.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were
but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as
you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for
you and dote upon the exchange.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth
with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on
the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his
ear that he is in her heart.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And so she doth, cousin.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the
world but I, and I am sunburnt; I may sit in a
corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I would rather have one of your father's getting.
Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you? Your
father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Will you have me, lady?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: No, my lord, unless I might have another for
working-days: your grace is too costly to wear
every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I
was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best
becomes you; for, out of question, you were born in
a merry hour.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there
was a star danced, and under that was I born.
Cousins, God give you joy!

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your grace's pardon.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: There's little of the melancholy element in her, my
lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps, and
not ever sad then; for I have heard my daughter say,
she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked
herself with laughing.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married,
they would talk themselves mad.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: To-morrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love
have all his rites.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just
seven-night; and a time too brief, too, to have all
things answer my mind.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing:
but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go
dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of
Hercules' labours; which is, to bring Signior
Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of
affection the one with the other. I would fain have
it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if
you three will but minister such assistance as I
shall give you direction.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten
nights' watchings.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And I, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: And you too, gentle Hero?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my
cousin to a good husband.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that
I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of a noble
strain, of approved valour and confirmed honesty. I
will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she
shall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your
two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in
despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he
shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this,
Cupid is no longer an archer: his glory shall be
ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me,
and I will tell you my drift.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the
daughter of Leonato.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be
medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to him,
and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges
evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this marriage?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no
dishonesty shall appear in me.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Show me briefly how.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: I think I told your lordship a year since, how much
I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting
gentlewoman to Hero.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I remember.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night,
appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to
the prince your brother; spare not to tell him that
he hath wronged his honour in marrying the renowned
Claudio--whose estimation do you mightily hold
up--to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: What proof shall I make of that?

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Proof enough to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio,
to undo Hero and kill Leonato. Look you for any
other issue?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Only to despite them, I will endeavour any thing.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Go, then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and
the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you know
that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the
prince and Claudio, as,--in love of your brother's
honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's
reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the
semblance of a maid,--that you have discovered
thus. They will scarcely believe this without trial:
offer them instances; which shall bear no less
likelihood than to see me at her chamber-window,
hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me
Claudio; and bring them to see this the very night
before the intended wedding,--for in the meantime I
will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be
absent,--and there shall appear such seeming truth
of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall be called
assurance and all the preparation overthrown.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put
it in practise. Be cunning in the working this, and
thy fee is a thousand ducats.

linegroup.speaker: BORACHIO
linegroup.line: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning
shall not shame me.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

section.title: SCENE III. LEONATO'S orchard.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Boy!

linegroup.speaker: Boy
linegroup.line: Signior?

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither
to me in the orchard.

linegroup.speaker: Boy
linegroup.line: I am here already, sir.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again.
I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much
another man is a fool when he dedicates his
behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at
such shallow follies in others, become the argument
of his own scorn by failing in love: and such a man
is Claudio. I have known when there was no music
with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he
rather hear the tabour and the pipe: I have known
when he would have walked ten mile a-foot to see a
good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake,
carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to
speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man
and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his
words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many
strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with
these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not
be sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster; but
I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster
of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman
is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am
well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all
graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in
my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise,
or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her;
fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or come not
near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good
discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall
be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and
Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.

section.para: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Come, shall we hear this music?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,
As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: O, very well, my lord: the music ended,
We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
To slander music any more than once.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: It is the witness still of excellency
To put a strange face on his own perfection.
I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,
Yet will he swear he loves.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Now, pray thee, come;
Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: Note this before my notes;
There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;
Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it
not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out
of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when
all's done.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in sea and one on shore,
To one thing constant never:
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blithe and bonny,
Converting all your sounds of woe
Into Hey nonny, nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,
Of dumps so dull and heavy;
The fraud of men was ever so,
Since summer first was leafy:
Then sigh not so, &c.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: By my troth, a good song.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: And an ill singer, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,
they would have hanged him: and I pray God his bad
voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the
night-raven, come what plague could have come after
it.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee,
get us some excellent music; for to-morrow night we
would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.

linegroup.speaker: BALTHASAR
linegroup.line: The best I can, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Do so: farewell.
Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of
to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with
Signior Benedick?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: O, ay: stalk on. stalk on; the fowl sits. I did
never think that lady would have loved any man.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she
should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in
all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think
of it but that she loves him with an enraged
affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: May be she doth but counterfeit.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Faith, like enough.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of
passion came so near the life of passion as she
discovers it.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard
my daughter tell you how.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: She did, indeed.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: How, how, pray you? You amaze me: I would have I
thought her spirit had been invincible against all
assaults of affection.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially
against Benedick.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I should think this a gull, but that the
white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot,
sure, hide himself in such reverence.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: 'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: 'Shall
I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered him
with scorn, write to him that I love him?'

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: This says she now when she is beginning to write to
him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and
there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a
sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a
pretty jest your daughter told us of.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she
found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: That.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence;
railed at herself, that she should be so immodest
to write to one that she knew would flout her; 'I
measure him,' says she, 'by my own spirit; for I
should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I
love him, I should.'

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,
beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; 'O
sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the
ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter
is sometime afeared she will do a desperate outrage
to herself: it is very true.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some
other, if she will not discover it.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: To what end? He would make but a sport of it and
torment the poor lady worse.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an
excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion,
she is virtuous.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And she is exceeding wise.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: In every thing but in loving Benedick.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender
a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath
the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just
cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I would
have daffed all other respects and made her half
myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear
what a' will say.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Were it good, think you?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she
will die, if he love her not, and she will die, ere
she make her love known, and she will die, if he woo
her, rather than she will bate one breath of her
accustomed crossness.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: She doth well: if she should make tender of her
love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the
man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: He is a very proper man.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And I take him to be valiant.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of
quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he
avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes
them with a most Christian-like fear.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace:
if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a
quarrel with fear and trembling.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: And so will he do; for the man doth fear God,
howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests
he will make. Well I am sorry for your niece. Shall
we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with
good counsel.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter:
let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and I
could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see
how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never
trust my expectation.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Let there be the same net spread for her; and that
must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The
sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of
another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the
scene that I would see, which will be merely a
dumb-show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

section.para: Exeunt DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Coming forward This can be no trick: the
conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of
this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it
seems her affections have their full bent. Love me!
why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured:
they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive
the love come from her; they say too that she will
rather die than give any sign of affection. I did
never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy
are they that hear their detractions and can put
them to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a
truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; 'tis
so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving
me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor
no great argument of her folly, for I will be
horribly in love with her. I may chance have some
odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me,
because I have railed so long against marriage: but
doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat
in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.
Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of
the brain awe a man from the career of his humour?
No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would
die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I
were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day!
she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in
her.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take
pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would
not have come.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: You take pleasure then in the message?

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's
point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach,
signior: fare you well.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to bid you come in
to dinner;' there's a double meaning in that 'I took
no more pains for those thanks than you took pains
to thank me.' that's as much as to say, Any pains
that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do
not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not
love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor;
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the prince and Claudio:
Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse
Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites,
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,
To listen our purpose. This is thy office;
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

linegroup.speaker: MARGARET
linegroup.line: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit:
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hearsay.
Now begin;
For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggerds of the rock.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But Nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endeared.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: Sure, I think so;
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured,
But she would spell him backward: if fair-faced,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antique,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agate very vilely cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: No; rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with: one doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.
She cannot be so much without true judgment--
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have--as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: He is the only man of Italy.
Always excepted my dear Claudio.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

linegroup.speaker: URSULA
linegroup.line: She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.

linegroup.speaker: HERO
linegroup.line: If it proves so, then loving goes by haps:
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

linegroup.speaker: BEATRICE
linegroup.line: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.

section.title: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
section.para: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and
then go I toward Arragon.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll
vouchsafe me.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss
of your marriage as to show a child his new coat
and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold
with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown
of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all
mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's
bow-string and the little hangman dare not shoot at
him; he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his
tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his
tongue speaks.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: So say I methinks you are sadder.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: I hope he be in love.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in
him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad,
he wants money.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: I have the toothache.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Draw it.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Hang it!

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: What! sigh for the toothache?

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Where is but a humour or a worm.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has
it.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Yet say I, he is in love.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be
a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as, to be
a Dutchman today, a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the
shape of two countries at once, as, a German from
the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from
the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy
to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no
fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no
believing old signs: a' brushes his hat o'
mornings; what should that bode?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him,
and the old ornament of his cheek hath already
stuffed tennis-balls.

linegroup.speaker: LEONATO
linegroup.line: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him
out by that?

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: And when was he wont to wash his face?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear
what they say of him.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into
a lute-string and now governed by stops.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,
conclude he is in love.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Nay, but I know who loves him.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of
all, dies for him.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

linegroup.speaker: BENEDICK
linegroup.line: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old
signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight
or nine wise words to speak to you, which these
hobby-horses must not hear.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this
played their parts with Beatrice; and then the two
bears will not bite one another when they meet.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: My lord and brother, God save you!

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Good den, brother.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: In private?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for
what I would speak of concerns him.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: What's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: To CLAUDIO Means your lordship to be married
to-morrow?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: You know he does.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: You may think I love you not: let that appear
hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will
manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you
well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect
your ensuing marriage;--surely suit ill spent and
labour ill bestowed.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Why, what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances
shortened, for she has been too long a talking of,
the lady is disloyal.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Who, Hero?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero:

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: Disloyal?

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness; I
could say she were worse: think you of a worse
title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till
further warrant: go but with me to-night, you shall
see her chamber-window entered, even the night
before her wedding-day: if you love her then,
to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour
to change your mind.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: May this be so?

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: I will not think it.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not
that you know: if you will follow me, I will show
you enough; and when you have seen more and heard
more, proceed accordingly.

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: If I see any thing to-night why I should not marry
her to-morrow in the congregation, where I should
wed, there will I shame her.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join
with thee to disgrace her.

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: I will disparage her no farther till you are my
witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and
let the issue show itself.

linegroup.speaker: DON PEDRO
linegroup.line: O day untowardly turned!

linegroup.speaker: CLAUDIO
linegroup.line: O mischief strangely thwarting!

linegroup.speaker: DON JOHN
linegroup.line: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when
you have seen the sequel.

section.title: SCENE III. A street.
section.para: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Are you good men and true?

linegroup.speaker: VERGES
linegroup.line: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer
salvation, body and soul.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if
they should have any allegiance in them, being
chosen for the prince's watch.

linegroup.speaker: VERGES
linegroup.line: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: First, who think you the most desertless man to be
constable?

linegroup.speaker: First Watchman
linegroup.line: Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can
write and read.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed
you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man is
the gift of fortune; but to write and read comes by nature.

linegroup.speaker: Second Watchman
linegroup.line: Both which, master constable,--

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well,
for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make
no boast of it; and for your writing and reading,
let that appear when there is no need of such
vanity. You are thought here to be the most
senseless and fit man for the constable of the
watch; therefore bear you the lantern. This is your
charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are
to bid any man stand, in the prince's name.

linegroup.speaker: Second Watchman
linegroup.line: How if a' will not stand?

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go; and
presently call the rest of the watch together and
thank God you are rid of a knave.

linegroup.speaker: VERGES
linegroup.line: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none
of the prince's subjects.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: True, and they are to meddle with none but the
prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise in
the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to
talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

linegroup.speaker: Watchman
linegroup.line: We will rather sleep than talk: we know what
belongs to a watch.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet
watchman; for I cannot see how sleeping should
offend: only, have a care that your bills be not
stolen. Well, you are to call at all the
ale-houses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

linegroup.speaker: Watchman
linegroup.line: How if they will not?

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober: if
they make you not then the better answer, you may
say they are not the men you took them for.

linegroup.speaker: Watchman
linegroup.line: Well, sir.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue
of your office, to be no true man; and, for such
kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them,
why the more is for your honesty.

linegroup.speaker: Watchman
linegroup.line: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay
hands on him?

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable
way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him
show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

linegroup.speaker: VERGES
linegroup.line: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more
a man who hath any honesty in him.

linegroup.speaker: VERGES
linegroup.line: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call
to the nurse and bid her still it.

linegroup.speaker: Watchman
linegroup.line: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

linegroup.speaker: DOGBERRY
linegroup.line: Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child wake
her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her
lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

linegroup.speaker: VERGES
linegroup.line: 'Tis very true.
